name: Banana Peel
description: The soft outer layer of a banana, rich in potassium and other nutrients, that breaks down naturally when exposed to microorganisms in soil.
disposal: Toss into your home compost bin or local green-waste collection. If neither is available, bury under a thin layer of soil to accelerate decomposition.
tips: Cut into smaller pieces before composting to speed up the breakdown process and prevent matting.

name: Apple Core
description: The central part of the apple fruit containing seeds and fibrous material, which readily decomposes under the right composting conditions.
disposal: Add directly to your backyard compost pile or municipal organics bin. Avoid sending it to landfill where it will produce methane.
tips: Chop into quarters to help it decompose more evenly and mix with dry leaves or paper to balance moisture.

name: Coffee Grounds
description: Used grounds from brewed coffee; slightly acidic and high in nitrogen, making them an excellent addition to compost.
disposal: Sprinkle into compost or use as a soil amendment in garden beds to improve structure and nutrient content.
tips: Dry leftover grounds on a tray before composting to prevent clumping; they can also deter slugs when sprinkled around plants.

name: Plastic Bottle (PET)
description: Transparent, lightweight polyethylene terephthalate containers commonly used for water and soft drinks; fully recyclable in most curbside programs.
disposal: Rinse out residue, remove caps and labels if required by your local facility, then place in the recyclables bin.
tips: Crush or flatten bottles to save space, and keep caps on loosely to avoid losing them in recycling machinery.

name: Aluminum Can
description: Durable, lightweight beverage cans made from aluminum, which can be recycled indefinitely without loss of quality.
disposal: Rinse out any liquid, then deposit into your metal recycling stream or container.
tips: Crush cans flat to maximize bin capacity and prevent them from rolling out when transporting.

name: Glass Jar
description: Sturdy glass containers used for food storage (e.g., jams, sauces) that are highly reusable and recyclable.
disposal: Remove lids and rinse thoroughly, then place in your glass recycling bin. Lids often go in the metal recycling stream.
tips: Reuse jars for home storage before recycling—perfect for spices, seeds, or homemade preserves.

name: Styrofoam Cup
description: Lightweight, white expanded polystyrene cups used for hot and cold beverages; breaks into harmful microplastics and does not biodegrade.
disposal: Check for a local drop-off that accepts EPS (expanded polystyrene) for densification and recycling; otherwise, it must go to general waste.
tips: Switch to reusable or compostable cups to reduce reliance on Styrofoam altogether.

name: Used Battery (AA/AAA)
description: Household batteries contain heavy metals (e.g., cadmium, nickel) that can leach into soil and water if landfilled, posing environmental hazards.
disposal: Take to a designated battery‐recycling or hazardous‐waste drop‐off point; do not place in regular trash or recycling bins.
tips: Store spent batteries in a sealed, labeled container at home and drop off once full to minimize handling.

name: Eggshells
description: Hard outer shell from eggs that is rich in calcium and breaks down in compost over time.
disposal: Crush shells and add to your compost bin or garden soil to improve structure and nutrient content.
tips: Rinse and bake shells before crushing to remove bacteria and make them more brittle for faster breakdown.

name: Grass Clippings
description: Green plant material left over after mowing grass, high in moisture and nitrogen.
disposal: Leave on lawn as mulch, add to compost if mixing with dry brown materials to avoid matting.
tips: Use a mulching mower to finely chop clippings, helping them decompose quickly and return nutrients to soil.

name: Fallen Leaves
description: Dry leaves shed by trees in autumn, composed of carbon-rich material ideal for composting.
disposal: Collect and add to compost pile or use as mulch around garden plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds.
tips: Shred leaves before composting to speed decomposition and prevent clumping into a solid layer.

name: Tea Bags
description: Used tea leaves contained in porous bags; many are now compostable but check the tag for plastic content.
disposal: Open and add leaves to compost; dispose of the bag (if plastic) in landfill or recycling per local guidelines.
tips: Remove staple and string before composting; use dried leaves as garden mulch to repel pests.

name: Vegetable Scraps
description: Peels, ends, and cores from vegetables which decompose quickly under proper composting conditions.
disposal: Collect in a compost bin or organic waste collection. Avoid adding large woody stems to home compost.
tips: Chop scraps into smaller pieces to accelerate breakdown and mix with dry material to balance moisture.

name: Paper Napkin
description: Disposable paper tissues used during meals, typically absorbent and made from wood pulp.
disposal: If lightly soiled with food, compost them. If heavily greasy or containing chemicals, discard in general waste.
tips: Ensure napkins do not contain synthetic dyes or coatings before composting.

name: Flower Trimmings
description: Dead or pruned parts of flowers and plants, including petals and stems, rich in organic matter.
disposal: Add to compost or green-waste bin. Chop thicker stems to help them decompose faster.
tips: Mix with other green and brown compostables to maintain air flow and moisture balance.

name: Peanut Shells
description: Hard outer shells from peanuts which decompose slowly but are still organic.
disposal: Crush and add to compost or use as mulch around plants to retain moisture and deter weeds.
tips: Break into smaller pieces to speed composting and prevent long decay times.

name: Cardboard Box
description: Corrugated cardboard packaging commonly used for shipping and storage, made from cellulose fibers.
disposal: Flatten and place in curbside recycling. Remove any tape or labels before recycling if possible.
tips: Reuse boxes for storage or crafts before recycling to extend their lifespan.

name: Newspaper
description: Printed newsprint paper that is recyclable and made primarily from wood pulp.
disposal: Place in paper recycling bin. Avoid mixing with glossy or coated papers.
tips: Use old newspapers as weed barrier under mulch or for cleaning glass surfaces.

name: Steel Can
description: Metal cans used for foods like vegetables and soups, made from steel coated with tin to prevent corrosion.
disposal: Rinse and place in metal recycling. Remove labels if required by local guidelines.
tips: Crush the can to save space and ensure it is completely dry to avoid rust in recycling bins.

name: Aluminum Foil
description: Thin sheet of aluminum used for wrapping food; can be recycled if cleaned of food residue.
disposal: Clean off any food scraps, roll into a ball at least 2 inches in diameter, then recycle with metals.
tips: Collect small foil pieces in a single ball to prevent them from falling through recycling machinery.

name: Plastic #2 Container
description: Rigid high-density polyethylene (HDPE) used for milk jugs, detergent bottles, and juice containers.
disposal: Rinse thoroughly and recycle in plastic stream. Replace caps loosely to ease separation during processing.
tips: Check the recycle symbol and local guidelines, as some areas only accept specific plastic numbers.

name: Plastic #5 Container
description: Polypropylene containers found in yogurt cups and margarine tubs; recyclable in many but not all programs.
disposal: Rinse and check local recycling rules for acceptance. If not accepted, repurpose or place in general waste.
tips: Use these sturdy tubs for organizing small items at home before choosing to recycle.

name: Glass Bottle (Colored)
description: Green or brown glass bottles typically used for beer and wine; separated from clear glass in recycling.
disposal: Rinse, remove caps, and sort by color into designated glass bins to ensure proper recycling.
tips: Reuse as decorative vases or storage before recycling to maximize reuse.

name: Plastic Bag
description: Thin film bags made from polyethylene, commonly used for groceries; prone to tangling and wildlife hazards.
disposal: Take to designated drop-off points at grocery stores for film plastic recycling; otherwise, place in trash.
tips: Switch to reusable cloth bags to reduce single-use plastic consumption.

name: Plastic Straw
description: Narrow plastic tubes for drinking beverages; too small to be captured by most recycling equipment.
disposal: Place in general waste. Consider switching to reusable or paper alternatives.
tips: Carry a metal or silicone straw for personal use to avoid disposable straws altogether.

name: Cigarette Butt
description: Filters made from cellulose acetate that can take years to break down, leaching toxins into the environment.
disposal: Dispose in a secure outdoor ashtray or trash can. Never discard on the ground.
tips: Use a pocket ashtray when outdoors to contain butts for proper disposal later.

name: Disposable Diaper
description: Layered plastic and paper product that absorbs liquid; contains superabsorbent polymers and can take centuries to decompose.
disposal: Seal in a plastic bag and discard in general waste. Do not flush or compost.
tips: Consider biodegradable or cloth diaper options to reduce landfill waste.

name: Cotton Swab
description: Small sticks with cotton tips, often made with plastic stems; cotton may biodegrade but the stick remains in landfill.
disposal: Trim off cotton tip and compost if unbleached; place stick in trash.
tips: Switch to bamboo or paper-stem swabs that are fully compostable.

name: Disposable Razor
description: Razors made from a combination of plastic and metal blades, challenging to recycle in standard streams.
disposal: Separate metal blade from handle if possible; recycle metal and discard plastic in trash.
tips: Invest in a safety razor with replaceable blades and a metal handle for a long-term, low-waste option.

name: Paint Can
description: Containers holding leftover paint, which may contain solvents and heavy metals harmful to water and soil.
disposal: Allow paint to fully dry out with kitty litter or commercial paint hardener, then take to hazardous waste facility.
tips: Donate excess paint to community groups or use up smaller amounts on sample projects before disposal.

name: Motor Oil
description: Used engine oil contains heavy metals and toxic additives that can contaminate soil and waterways if poured down drains or onto the ground.
disposal: Collect in a sealed, clearly labeled container and take to an automotive parts store or hazardous-waste drop-off facility.
tips: Never mix with water or other fluids; keep it covered to prevent spills and volatilization.

name: Compact Fluorescent Lamp (CFL)
description: Energy-saving light bulbs that contain small amounts of mercury vapor; breakage releases mercury, which is harmful to health and environment.
disposal: Return intact bulbs to a recycling center or retail drop-off that accepts mercury lamps; never throw in regular trash.
tips: Store spent CFLs in a sturdy box to avoid breakage until you can take them to a proper facility.

name: Expired Medication
description: Packs or bottles of out-of-date pharmaceuticals, which can leach active compounds into water systems if flushed or landfilled.
disposal: Bring to a pharmacy take-back program or community hazardous-waste event; do not flush or toss in household trash.
tips: Keep all expired meds in their original containers and tape lids closed to prevent accidental ingestion.

name: Printer Toner Cartridge
description: Plastic cartridges filled with fine toner powder that can pose inhalation hazards and are not accepted in normal recycling bins.
disposal: Return to manufacturer or office-supply store for free cartridge recycling or drop-off at an e-waste collection point.
tips: Handle gently to avoid powder spills; many brands offer mail-back recycling kits.

name: Lithium-Ion Battery (Phone/Laptop)
description: Rechargeable batteries containing lithium that can ignite if damaged or improperly disposed; contain metals harmful to the environment.
disposal: Take to an electronics retailer or specialized battery-recycling kiosk; do not place in curbside recycling or trash.
tips: Tape over terminals and store in a fire-resistant container until drop-off.

name: Pesticide Container
description: Empty or partly used plastic jugs and bottles that held herbicides, insecticides, or fungicides; residues can be toxic to wildlife.
disposal: Triple-rinse on site, add rinsate to your sprayer, then bring container to a household hazardous-waste facility.
tips: Never reuse pesticide containers for any other purpose, and keep rinse water contained.

name: Bleach Bottle
description: Plastic containers that held bleach or other strong oxidizers; leftover chemical can corrode pipes and harm wastewater treatment.
disposal: Rinse thoroughly, allow to air-dry, then recycle plastic per your municipality’s guidelines or take to hazardous-waste drop-off.
tips: Wear gloves when rinsing and keep cap off so the container drains fully.

name: Cooking Oil
description: Used vegetable or animal fats that can clog drainage systems and attract pests if poured down the sink.
disposal: Let cool, pour into a sealed, disposable container (e.g., an old carton) and place in general waste or take to a recycling center that accepts used cooking oil.
tips: Filter out food particles and reuse oil when possible; store the disposal container upright in a cool place.

name: CD/DVD
description: Optical discs made from polycarbonate plastic coated with metal and lacquer; degrade very slowly in landfills.
disposal: Take to an electronics recycling event or mail-back program; never put loose discs in the curbside bin where they can jam sorting equipment.
tips: Repurpose scratched or obsolete discs as craft material or decorative art before recycling.

name: Synthetic Textile (Clothing)
description: Garments made from polyester, nylon, or acrylic that shed microplastics when washed and take centuries to break down.
disposal: Donate wearable items; for worn-out fabrics, take to a textile-recycling drop-off or use as cleaning rags.
tips: Check for local “clothing bank” bins to keep textiles out of landfill.

name: Rubber Tire
description: Vehicle tires composed of synthetic rubber and steel belts that resist natural degradation and can trap methane in landfills.
disposal: Return to tire retailer for ‘take-back’ recycling or bring to a municipal solid-waste facility offering tire collection.
tips: Many communities repurpose tires for playground surfaces or as garden planters—consider upcycling first.

name: Ceramic Plate
description: Dinnerware made from glazed clay; cannot be melted down or reshaped at typical glass-recycling facilities.
disposal: Wrap broken pieces in newspaper and place in general waste; for whole items, consider donating if intact.
tips: Use chipped plates as stepping stones in your garden or plant labels after gluing to stakes.

name: PVC Pipe
description: Rigid plastic piping used in plumbing; contains additives that make it difficult to recycle in standard plastic streams.
disposal: Take clean, cut-to-length sections to a construction-and-demolition recycling center; otherwise, dispose of as bulky waste.
tips: Reuse off-cuts for garden trellises or conduit for low-voltage wiring.

name: LCD Television
description: Flat-screen TVs contain mercury backlights and circuit boards with lead and other toxic metals.
disposal: Take to an e-waste drop-off or electronics retailer with a recycling program; do not leave curbside.
tips: Donate working units to schools or community centers before resorting to recycling.

name: Photographic Film
description: Traditional film negatives and prints contain silver halide crystals and chemical coatings harmful to water systems.
disposal: Send to a specialty photo-lab recycling program or hazardous-waste facility; do not compost or trash loose.
tips: Store film in a sealed plastic bag until you have enough to ship in bulk.

name: Aerosol Can
description: Pressurized spray containers that may contain flammable propellants and corrosive chemicals.
disposal: Ensure can is empty (spray until hissing stops), then recycle metal body per local metal-recycling rules; full or partially full cans belong at hazardous-waste drop-off.
tips: Puncture only at authorized facilities; never try to crush a full can yourself.

name: Nail Polish
description: Solvent-based cosmetic containing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and resins that can pollute air and water.
disposal: Let small amounts air-dry in a ventilated area, then discard the hardened residue in general waste; for larger volumes, take to chemical-waste collection.
tips: Donate unopened bottles or swap with friends; use all polish in small craft projects to avoid disposal.

name: Mirror Glass
description: Reflective glass backed with silver or aluminum; cannot be recycled with standard container or window glass due to the reflective coating.
disposal: Wrap in thick layers of paper or bubble wrap and place in general waste; check if your local scrap yard accepts mirror glass.
tips: Reframe or repurpose old mirrors as decorative accents or craft supplies.

name: Disposable Surgical Mask
description: Single-use face mask made from polypropylene micro-fibers designed to filter droplets; not recyclable and can take decades to break down in landfill.
disposal: Seal in a small plastic bag and discard in general waste; never flush masks or litter them outdoors.
tips: Switch to reusable cloth masks when possible and wash regularly to reduce single-use waste.

name: Nitrile Glove
description: Single-use protective glove made from synthetic nitrile rubber; resists tears and chemicals but is not compostable.
disposal: Place in general waste; if contaminated with biohazardous material, follow your local medical-waste protocol.
tips: For non-medical tasks (e.g., cleaning), consider heavier reusable gloves to cut down on waste.

name: Medical Sharps (Needles)
description: Used syringes and needles pose puncture and infection risks; must be contained to protect handlers and the environment.
disposal: Store in an approved sharps container and return to a pharmacy or hazardous-waste facility for safe destruction.
tips: Never recap needles; seal containers when three-quarters full and label clearly “Sharps—Do Not Recycle.”

name: Mercury Thermometer
description: Glass thermometer containing elemental mercury, a potent neurotoxin that vaporizes if the tube breaks.
disposal: Take intact units to a hazardous-waste drop-off; never toss in regular trash or break open at home.
tips: Replace with digital or alcohol-based thermometers to eliminate mercury risks.

name: Lead-Acid Car Battery
description: Automotive battery with lead plates and sulfuric acid electrolyte; extremely toxic and corrosive if leaked.
disposal: Return to any auto parts retailer or battery-recycling center—they’ll accept and recycle it free of charge.
tips: Keep upright and tape terminals; store in a leak-proof tray until disposal.

name: Printer Ink Cartridge
description: Plastic cartridge filled with solvent-based ink that may contain heavy metals and volatile organic compounds.
disposal: Use manufacturer mail-back or office-supply store recycling programs; do not toss in curbside bins.
tips: Opt for refillable ink systems or high-yield cartridges to reduce replacement frequency.

name: Polystyrene Packing Peanuts
description: Loose-fill foam packaging made from expanded polystyrene; lightweight and prone to scattering into waterways.
disposal: Drop off at shipping stores offering foam recycling; otherwise seal in a bag and send to trash.
tips: Collect and reuse for future shipments or donate to local mail-order businesses.

name: Candle Wax Residue
description: Leftover paraffin or soy wax from burned candles; soy wax is compostable, but paraffin is petroleum-based.
disposal: Skim cooled wax from jars: compost soy wax with green waste; discard paraffin in general trash.
tips: Filter and remelt leftover wax to create new candles, mixing in wicks and fragrance as desired.

name: Cotton Bath Towel
description: Thick absorbent towel made from 100% natural cotton fibers; fully compostable when cut into strips.
disposal: Donate gently used towels; cut worn-out ones into rags or small pieces and add to backyard compost.
tips: Use old towels as pet bedding or cleaning cloths before composting the scraps.

name: Cork Wine Stopper
description: Stoppers made from harvested cork oak bark; natural, renewable, and compostable material.
disposal: Drop off at cork-recycling points (often found in wine shops) or toss in home compost.
tips: Repurpose as coasters, plant markers, or bulletin-board tacks before composting.

name: Leather Belt
description: Accessory crafted from animal hide that, if untreated, will slowly break down in soil over time.
disposal: Donate or sell if wearable; otherwise cut into small sections and compost untreated leather scraps.
tips: Use durable leather offcuts for DIY projects like keychains or bracelets to extend their life.

name: Wool Sweater
description: Garment knitted from sheep’s wool, a natural protein fiber that can biodegrade in controlled composting.
disposal: Donate wearable sweaters; for damaged ones, cut into pieces and send to textile composting or recycling bins.
tips: Moth-proof and repair holes to prolong life; small bits can be used as stuffing or insulation.

name: Oil-Based Paint
description: Solvent-based paint containing volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and heavy metals; flammable.
disposal: Allow paint to harden fully (with cat litter or commercial hardener) then take cans to hazardous-waste collection.
tips: Use water-based (latex) paints when possible and buy only what you’ll use to avoid leftovers.

name: Cosmetic Glass Jar
description: Small glass container for creams or balms; highly reusable and accepted by curbside glass recycling.
disposal: Rinse out all residue, remove plastic lids, and sort glass into recycling; recycle lids separately per material.
tips: Upcycle jars as spice holders, travel containers, or DIY candle vessels before recycling.

name: Shredded Paper
description: Finely cut paper from documents or packaging; must be bagged to prevent jamming sorting machinery.
disposal: Place in a clear plastic bag and deposit in paper-recycling bins; do not mix loose with other recyclables.
tips: Use as packing fill or compost as a brown material, balancing with nitrogen-rich scraps.

name: Wooden Furniture Offcuts
description: Scraps of untreated wood from carpentry, ideal for mulch or compost when chipped or shredded.
disposal: Chop into smaller pieces and add to compost heaps; larger offcuts can be turned into wood chips.
tips: Donate usable offcuts to makerspaces or community workshops before composting.

name: Rice Husk
description: Fibrous outer layer of rice grains removed during milling; high in silica and organic matter.
disposal: Use as garden mulch or compost with green materials; can also be used in animal bedding.
tips: Sift to remove dust before using as mulch to prevent respiratory irritation.

name: Tyvek Envelope
description: Light, tear-resistant envelope made from high-density polyethylene fibers; not accepted by curbside recycling.
disposal: Take to specialized drop-off points for mailing supplies or discard in regular trash.
tips: Reuse for shipping or document storage—carefully cut open to flatten and nest before disposal.
